description: The smallest unit of a chemical element, consisting of protons, neutrons, and electrons.
The process by which green plants and some organisms use sunlight to synthesize nutrients from carbon dioxide and water.
A force that attracts two bodies toward each other, proportional to their mass.
The process through which species change over time through natural selection and adaptation.
A group of atoms bonded together, representing the smallest unit of a chemical compound.
The basic structural and functional unit of living organisms.
Deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule that carries genetic information in living organisms.
A specialized cell transmitting nerve impulses in the brain and nervous system.
A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.
A large system of stars, stellar remnants, interstellar gas, dust, and dark matter, held together by gravity.
The theory that explains the origin of the universe as a rapid expansion from a hot, dense state.
The movement of water molecules through a semipermeable membrane from a less concentrated solution to a more concentrated one.
An influence that causes an object to undergo a change in motion, direction, or shape.
The energy possessed by an object due to its motion.
The theory explaining the movement of the Earth's lithospheric plates and the resulting geological activity.
A region in space where the gravitational pull is so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape.
A fundamental theory in physics describing the properties of nature on an atomic scale.
The study of heredity and the variation of inherited characteristics.
A process that leads to the transformation of one set of chemical substances into another.
Long-term changes in temperature, precipitation, and other atmospheric conditions on Earth.
